The constraint satisfaction problem with fixed template H𝐻H asks whether or not
an input relational system G𝐺G, with the same arities of corresponding
relations as H𝐻H, admits a homomorphism to H𝐻H. Note that when H𝐻H has a single relation S𝑆S, which is binary and symmetric,
then we obtain the graph homomorphism problem referred to at the beginning of
Section 1. When H𝐻H has a single relation S𝑆S, which is an
arbitrary binary relation, we obtain the digraph homomorphism
problem  which is in a certain sense  as difficult to
classify as the general constraint satisfaction problem. When H𝐻H has two
relations +,−+,-, then we obtain a problem that is superficially similar to
the homomorphism problem for signed graphs, except that switching is not
allowed. This problem is called the edge-coloured graph homomorphism
problem [ref]5, and it turns out to be similar to the digraph
homomorphism problem in that it is difficult to classify . On the
other hand, the homomorphism problem for signed
graphs  [ref]8 , seems easier to classify, and exhibits a
dichotomy similar to the graph dichotomy classification, see
Theorem 5. List homomorphism problems are also special cases of constraint satisfaction
problems, as lists can be replaced by unary relations. Consider first the case

One formulation of the dichotomy theorem proved by Bulatov  and
Zhuk  states that the constraint satisfaction problem for the
template H𝐻H is polynomial-time solvable if H𝐻H admits a Siggers polymorphism,
and is NP-complete otherwise. Majority polymorphisms are less powerful, but it
is known  that if H𝐻H admits a majority then the constraint
satisfaction problem for the template H𝐻H is polynomial-time solvable.
Moreover, it was shown in  that a graph H𝐻H is a bi-arc
graph if and only if the associated relational system H∗superscript𝐻H^{*} admits a majority
polymorphism. Thus the list homomorphism problem for a graph H𝐻H with possible
loops is polynomial-time solvable if H∗superscript𝐻H^{*} admits a majority polymorphism, and
is NP-complete otherwise. It was observed in 3 that this is not true
for signed graphs. There is a convenient way to think of polymorphisms f𝑓f of the relational
system (H+,π+)∗superscriptsuperscript𝐻superscript𝜋(H^{+},\pi^{+})^{*}. A mapping f𝑓f is a polymorphism of (H+,π+)∗superscriptsuperscript𝐻superscript𝜋(H^{+},\pi^{+})^{*}
if and only if it is a polymorphism of the edge-coloured graph (H+,π+)superscript𝐻superscript𝜋(H^{+},\pi^{+}) and if, for
any symmetric set X⊆V​(H+)𝑋𝑉superscript𝐻X\subseteq V(H^{+}), we have x1,x2,…,xt∈Xsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑡𝑋x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{t}\in X
then also f​(x1,x2,…,xt)∈X𝑓subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑡𝑋f(x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{t})\in X. We call such polymorphisms of
(H+,π+)superscript𝐻superscript𝜋(H^{+},\pi^{+}) semi-conservative. We can apply the dichotomy result of   to obtain an algebraic
classification. For any signed graph (H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi), the problem List-S-Hom(H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi) is
polynomial-time solvable if (H+,π+)superscript𝐻superscript𝜋(H^{+},\pi^{+}) admits a semi-conservative Siggers
polymorphism, and is NP-complete otherwise. As mentioned above, one can not replace the semi-conservative Siggers
polymorphism by a semi-conservative majority polymorphism 3.
We focus in this paper on seeking a graph theoretic classification, at least
for some classes of signed graphs.
